==English==
===Etymology=== From {{suffix|en|rugby|er|id2=Oxford|gloss1=Rugby football}} (Oxford “-er”). Compare contemporary {{m|en|soccer}}, from As'''soc'''iation football. Both words seem to have originated at the University of Oxford during the 1880s. See {{w|Oxford -er}}.
===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|en|/ˈɹʌɡə/|a=RP}} * {{IPA|en|/ˈɹʌɡɚ/|a=GA}} * {{audio|en|LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-rugger.wav|a=Southern England}} * {{rhymes|en|ʌɡə(ɹ)|s=2}} * {{hyphenation|en|rug|ger}}
===Noun=== {{en-noun|~}} [[File:National_Schools_Sevens_2016,_U13A_Semi-final_(fifth_try_-1).jpg|thumb]]

Macaulay |title=The Advance of Science |work=The Oxford Magazine |url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018052806?urlappend=%3Bseq=372 |page=356 |passage=That . . . . . . may for once put a full '''Rugger''' team in the field}} #* {{quote-journal |en |date=1888-02-15 |author= |title=Charley Symonds |work=The Oxford Magazine |url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015011426007?urlappend=%3Bseq=518 |page=224 |passage=Golf is perhaps seven or eight years old in Oxford, ... football, ''seu'' '''Rugger''', ''sive'' Soccer, not more than sixteen or seventeen.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1890 |editor= |author=Albert Barrère; Charles Leland |title=A Dictionary of Slang, Jargon & Cant |url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc2.ark:/13960/t28913p0h?urlappend=%3Bseq=201 |volume=2 |genre= |publisher=Ballantyne |location= |isbn= |page=191 |passage='''Rugger''' (schools), the Rugby game at football}} #* {{quote-book|1=en|year=1929|author=[[w:Arthur Conan Doyle|Sir Arthur Conan Doyle]]|title=When the World Screamed|url=http://gutenberg.net.au/ebooks01/0100031h.html|passage=It was clear to me that I was dealing with a lunatic, so I thought it well before I went any further in the matter to call upon my friend Malone, whom I had known since the old days when we both played '''Rugger''' for Richmond.}} #* {{quote-journal|en|year=1959|month=April|author=William Jones; John Hodge|title=Resorts for Railfans - 28 Cardiff|journal=Trains Illustrated|page=210|text=To complete the picture of the main line passenger workings, mention must be made of the excursions for International '''rugger''' and soccer matches. Genuine "'''Ruggers'''" will, of course, scoff at this}} #* {{quote-journal |en |date= |year=1974 |month=August |author=Paul Burka |coauthors= |title=The Sport of Rough Gentlemen |volume=2 |issue=8 |page=42 |magazine=Texas Monthly |publisher= |issn= |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=TCwEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42&dq=ruggers+-Life&source=bl&ots=l2GGKPBxjz&sig=4znUYG_wb1kmbDXImS-08bP_Bq0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=kPJmULzEBqy20AHMqYGABQ&ved=0CDgQ6AEwATg8 |passage=To this day '''ruggers''' belittle soccer, and they will tell anyone who expresses the slightest interest in their game that rugby is "a ruffian's game played by gentlemen," while soccer is "a gentleman's game played by ruffians." }} #* {{quote-journal |en |date= |year=1977 ...
